entry.title: Can a Slack bot inspire serendipity at work?

link.title: Can a Slack bot inspire serendipity at work?

entry.content:
At any given moment, people are doing some pretty neat stuff at The Atlantic. Just last week, my coworkers:

  • Wrote a story about snakes that are good at killing other snakes;

  • Experimented with how to hype a magazine story in a really cool way on Instagram;

  • Compiled a crazy photo essay on Mount Etna, Europe‚Äôs most active volcano.

But here‚Äôs the sad truth: I only see a tiny percentage of the things my officemates make. I just don‚Äôt have enough time in the day to read through every story on theatlantic.com. And even if I could, I‚Äôd still miss all the things our events staffers are planning, or what the product team is coding, or what the graphic artists are cooking up‚Ä¶

We all work in the same building, but I know very little about what people outside my own team (politics) do on a daily basis. And although I don‚Äôt really need to, I wondered if there was a way to introduce some serendipity into our working lives.

Why is serendipity even important?
This probably deserves a longer answer, and at some point, I‚Äôll write a standalone post.

For now, here‚Äôs my best shot: Encouraging serendipity at an organization makes room for happy accidents, where something unexpected results from the collision of two separate things. Some of my favorite projects have come from chance conversations ‚Äî and they‚Äôre usually something neither me nor my conversation partner would have developed alone.

Enter SerendipityBot

They say that if all you have is a hammer, everything looks like a nail. I‚Äôm trying to be more careful about jumping to a technical solution when something might just need a simple conversation ‚Äî or might not be a problem at all.

But in this case, I felt pretty confident about my idea: What if we had a Slack bot that unobtrusively asked random staffers about what‚Äôs energizing them this week, and then shared that with the office at large?

Here was my idea:

  • I‚Äôd make a Slack #serendipity channel where people who are interested in learning about what their coworkers do ‚Äî and telling their own stories ‚Äî could join and engage in conversation;

  • I‚Äôd code a Slack bot that would randomly ping people from that channel to share what they‚Äôre passionate about at that moment, at an interval of no more than once every two weeks or so.

  • Every day, the bot would ping coworkers during working hours until it had three responses. And at a set time, it would post all three to the #serendipity channel as a small blog post.

Would anyone even want to participate? I floated a trial balloon:

OK, so I wasn‚Äôt crazy! Those 25 people became my beta testers.

First job was figuring out what the bot would say to people. I wanted it to be chill and non-threatening, and give people the option of ducking out ‚Äî but also be fairly direct.

Here‚Äôs what I ended up with:

The bot waits a while for an answer. If it doesn‚Äôt get one, it nudges politely: ‚ÄúI‚Äôll ask one more time before leaving you alone: Any chance you want to share a cool thing you‚Äôre working on this week?‚Äù

It‚Äôs key, by the way, to give people a way to let the bot know they don‚Äôt really have anything they want to share. Sometimes, you‚Äôre just not working on anything exciting at the moment. Or maybe you‚Äôre too busy. In that case, the bot happily accepts snooze and leaves the person alone for two weeks.

Right now, I have the bot pinging a random employee every 10 minutes, from 11 a.m. to 2 p.m., Monday through Friday. Once it gets three responses, it stops for the day. (Of course, sometimes people respond a few hours late, after the quota has already been filled, so we‚Äôll occasionally have four or even five responses in a single day.)

At the stroke of 2:30 p.m. ‚Äî I originally set it for the next morning, but people didn‚Äôt like waiting a whole day to see their responses go up ‚Äî the bot posts in #serendipity.

Here‚Äôs an example:

How has this experiment turned out?

Pretty well. More than 70 people have joined the #serendipity channel ‚Äî somewhere around a quarter of the entire Atlantic Slack community. SerendipityBot had some hiccups: It spammed a bunch of people on Martin Luther King Jr. Day, which is on a Monday, when the bot thought everyone would be working. But overall, I think it has made each day a teensy bit more delightful.

What‚Äôs the long term impact? I don‚Äôt know. So far, I haven‚Äôt seen The Next Big Atlantic Idea bubble up from a conversation in #serendipity. But that‚Äôs not really the point. Getting to know your coworkers better is a worthy goal on its own ‚Äî and I think SerendipityBot has helped with that.

If you‚Äôd like to look at the code powering SerendipityBot, it‚Äôs available here. Tldr: It‚Äôs a Node app that lives on Heroku and stores user information in a MongoDB database.

entry.title: Turning an Amazon IoT button into something actually useful with (almost) no code

link.title: Turning an Amazon IoT button into something actually useful with (almost) no code

entry.content:
I‚Äôm pretty nuts for Amazon‚Äôs internet-of-things button. I‚Äôve already made a Slack doorbell for my office and a push-to-order Sweetgreen button. But both of these projects required a fair amount of programming.

Why is this button interesting? Gooood question. I mean, you can‚Äôt do much with it, besides press it. But:

  • It combined a mechanical sensor with built-in WiFi, in a package that costs $20. That‚Äôs actually pretty incredible. Even the cheapest DIY setup would easily clock in at $30 or more, and would mostly likely be a great deal more bulky.

  • It ties into Amazon‚Äôs Lambda service. A few years ago, to do anything on the internet, you had to rent a server. They weren‚Äôt necessarily expensive ‚Äî Amazon‚Äôs been in the server game for a decade ‚Äî but they could be knowledge-intensive. You still had to do all the annoying initializing/maintenance stuff that many coders didn‚Äôt care for.

    Services like Lamda abstract this aaway ‚Äî¬†you pop in your code, and Amazon worries about the rest.

So it‚Äôs a pretty neat little button!

That said‚Ä¶

It‚Äôs not terribly useful if you don‚Äôt know how to program a computer. Amazon doesn‚Äôt hold your hand. You basically get a box to write code in, some weird parameters, and Lambda bids you good luck. For a novice, that‚Äôs pretty intimidating.

On the other end of the spectrum is IFTTT.com, an automation website that does a really good job of abstracting code into something easier to understand. The site (it stands for If This, Then That) links together completely separate services ‚Äî Twitter, Hue lightbulbs, thermostats ‚Äî and allows events from one to trigger actions in another.

Combinations that sound very complicated ‚Äî hmm, can I send a üôÑ tweet whenever I receive an email from my crazy uncle? ‚Äî become a matter of clicking and dragging various services together.

If only Amazon‚Äôs IoT service could be so intuitive‚Ä¶

But it can be!

It just takes a bit of boilerplate code, thanks to IFTTT‚Äôs Maker extension. Maker is sort of a general-purpose receiver, allowing people to trigger an action by sending a ping from an outside server through a humble POST request. (If you‚Äôre not familiar with HTTP protocol, a POST request is one of the four or five simplest messages servers use to talk to each other.)

Programmatically, sending an HTTP request is super easy ‚Äî pretty much any server can do it. And since you can write code to send the POST message yourself, it frees you from needing a device that already has a partnership with IFTTT.

So you could have a motion detector, hooked up to a Raspberry Pi, that tells IFTTT to text you every time someone walks past your desk. Or a water sensor, also connected to a Raspberry Pi, that pings IFTTT every time the cat‚Äôs water bowl gets low. In both cases, the Pi would take care of sending the ping.

In this case, Amazon‚Äôs Lambda service will take the place of the Pi (remember, we don‚Äôt need servers anymore?), pinging IFTTT every time we press the IoT button. For this demonstration, I‚Äôm going to make my button do something simple: tweet ‚ÄúMan, it‚Äôs a hot one‚Äù from my Twitter account.

Setting up IFTTT

Let‚Äôs do the easy bit first: Making our Twitter IFTTT action.

  • Head to IFTTT and make a new applet. (You‚Äôll have to sign up for an account if you haven‚Äôt already.)

  • Click ‚Äú+this‚Äù to make a new trigger. It‚Äôll give a wide array of options, but filter for ‚ÄúMaker.‚Äù

  • Choose the ‚ÄúRecieve a web request‚Äù option. It‚Äôll prompt you to give the trigger a name. I‚Äôm calling mine santana-button-pressed.

  • Now, we‚Äôll choose the action: sending a tweet. Click ‚Äú+that‚Äù and filter to Twitter, selecting ‚ÄúPost a tweet.‚Äù

  • Write your preferred tweet text. Here‚Äôs mine:

  • After I saved the applet, I had a bit of trouble finding the URL I was supposed to use to send a POST request to Maker. If you click ‚ÄúMaker‚Äù in the breadcrumb menu in the upper-left, and then click ‚ÄúSettings‚Äù on the main Maker page, you‚Äôll get a URL under ‚ÄúAccount info.‚Äù Following that takes you to your credential page. Whew!

    Now you have the URL you‚Äôll need to POST ‚Äî a combination of your trigger name and your Maker key. For instance, mine starts https://maker.ifttt.com/trigger/santana-button-pressed/with/key/ (followed by my key). Save this!

Writing the Node code to upload to Lambda

Now, we have to write a simple script for Lambda that sends a POST request every time the button is pushed. The POST request itself doesn‚Äôt even have to contain any information ‚Äî we‚Äôve already told IFTTT what to tweet.

Here‚Äôs my walk-through in Node. (If you‚Äôre not interested, here‚Äôs the code you‚Äôll need for the next part, when we upload our code to Lambda.)

  • Start a new project folder. We‚Äôll use the requests module to send the POST ping, so install that using npm install requests --save.

  • Make a main file for your code ‚Äî index.js works fine.

  • All Lambda Node scripts are written as modules, meaning we‚Äôll have to encase our code in a function and include it as a export property. So let‚Äôs start off with this:

    exports.ifttt = function(event, context){
}

    Everything else will go inside here.

  • Now let‚Äôs import the request library and make the actual request.

      exports.ifttt = function(event, context){
    var request = require('request');
    request.post(process.env.IFTTT_KEY, function(err, res, body){
      if(err) throw err;
      console.log("Sent ping to IFTTT!");
    });
  }

    Pretty simple. We make a POST request to our IFTTT endpoint, throw an error if one returns, and otherwise print that all is well. You‚Äôll note that we don‚Äôt actually include the endpoint in the code ‚Äî we‚Äôre telling Node to pull it from an environmental variable, which we‚Äôll specify when we set up Lambda. This is better for security‚Ä¶ you don‚Äôt wnat your private key floating around on Github.

Once you‚Äôve got that written, select all the files (index.js, node_modules, etc.) and compress into a zip archive.

Setting up IoT button and uploading code to Lambda

I‚Äôm presuming that you‚Äôre staring at a new IoT button in your hand and wondering what to do. Skip ahead if you‚Äôve already done some of these steps.

  • Log into https://aws.amazon.com Once there, select the ‚ÄúAWS IoT‚Äù service. Clicking ‚ÄúConnect‚Äù on the left rail will give you a new spread of menu options, one of which is ‚ÄúAWS IoT Button.‚Äù

  • Scroll down and click ‚ÄúGo to Configuration Wizard.‚Äù You‚Äôll have to type in your serial number, which is printed on the back of the button. Make sure you click ‚ÄúGenerate certificate and keys‚Äù before you move on! You‚Äôll be given two files to download, and I don‚Äôt know how to get these otherwise. Also note the endpoint and region.

  • Also make sure you click ‚ÄúEnable trigger‚Äù before you click ‚ÄúNext.‚Äù Then (finally!) click ‚ÄúNext.‚Äù

  • We‚Äôre now at the ‚ÄúConfigure function‚Äù section. Type ifttt into Name, and write whatever description you‚Äôd like. Down at Lambda function code, change ‚ÄúCode entry type‚Äù to ‚ÄúUpload a .ZIP file.‚Äù You‚Äôll then upload the zip archive we compressed a few steps ago.

    (Why aren‚Äôt we just copying-and-pasting our code? It‚Äôs that pesky requests library ‚Äî the meat of it is included in the node_modules folder, so we need to include everything.)

  • Make sure you add an environmental variable, named IFTTT_KEY, that lists the Maker URL you took from IFTTT.

  • Lastly, give the button code a descriptive role name ‚Äî I did ifttt_button. Click ‚ÄúNext,‚Äù and then ‚ÄúCreate function.‚Äù

  • OK! Your code should be uploaded. Only thing left to do is connect your IoT button to your home or office WiFi. Amazon has a pretty good set of directions here, so I‚Äôll let them explain. Just remember that you‚Äôll need those credentials you downloaded earlier! (And if you missed them, you‚Äôll find your endpoint by clicking ‚ÄúSettngs‚Äù at the AWS IoT console.)

Give it a shot. Boom!

Man, it's a hot one‚Äî Andrew McGill (@andrewmcgill) December 19, 2016

The button will now do your bidding.

Final notes

You can obviously set up your IFTTT account to do whatever you want, which is the beauty of this hack. I will note that I had a tough time getting my button to connect to my apartment WiFi until I realized it only can communicate with 2.4 GHz networks. If you‚Äôre running into connectivity issues (hint: the button‚Äôs LED will flash red three times), try poking around in your router settings.

Other than that, happy button-pushing!

entry.title: Make Every Week, Part 5: A real-life Harry Potter Lumos spell, using speech recognition

link.title: Make Every Week, Part 5: A real-life Harry Potter Lumos spell, using speech recognition

entry.content:
I don‚Äôt think of myself as a Harry Potter fan, but I somehow know a crapload of magic spells from the famous book series. Alohomora was useful for unlocking doors; Expelliarmus would disarm an opponent of her wand. But one of the simplest was Lumos, which lit the tip of a wizard‚Äôs wand, along with its counterpart Nox, which extinguished the light.

Speech recognition has always seemed a bit like magic to me, too. But as I poked around the open-source work being done using the Amazon Alexa Voice Service platform (which powers the Amazon Echo, Dot, etc.), I found Snowboy. It‚Äôs a pretty neat ‚Äúwake-word-as-service‚Äù library that‚Äôs free for hackers (real apps have to pay money), and uses machine learning to recognize the desired phrase. It‚Äôs especially nice because it doesn‚Äôt need the internet to work ‚Äî after you train the algorithm online using your own voice, Snowboy gives you a downloadable file that hooks up with its library offline.

Hmm, I thought. Could Snowboy help me achieve my dream of becoming an actual wizard?

Voila:

Last week needed some Raspberry Pi-powered ACTUAL HARRY POTTER MAGIC. Explainer post coming soon pic.twitter.com/u5AK25e3MG‚Äî Andrew McGill (@andrewmcgill) November 14, 2016

Building the Lumos Lamp

The goal was to turn on a lamp (or several) by saying ‚ÄúLumos!‚Äù out loud. Since I‚Äôm not comfortable enough with electrical engineering to hardwire a lamp‚Äôs power supply directly through my Raspberry Pi, I ended up buying the Powerswitch Tail 2, essentially an extension cord that can be powered on and off programmatically by a micontroller.

Here are the materials I used:

  • Raspberry Pi 2 (Model B in my case) with Raspbian installed
  • A USB microphone
  • Powerswitch Tail 2
  • A bunch of male-female jumper wires
  • Generic power strip

First, set up the Raspberry Pi. (Snowboy has some good documentation here.) Presuming you‚Äôve booted up the Pi and connected it to the internet, plug in your USB microphone. You‚Äôll need to install some audio dependencies from the command line:

sudo apt-get install python-pyaudio python3-pyaudio sox

You can check to see if that worked by running rec test.wav, speaking into the microphone for a few seconds, and then aplay test.wav. (You may need to do some more fiddling ‚Äî troubleshooting advice here).

At this point, it‚Äôs probably best to set up your project folder. I used Node.js to code this project, so we need to initiate NPM and install a snowboy, which will run our Pi‚Äôs speech recognition, onoff, which handles switching the power source, and node-record-lpcm16, a Node-specific audio recording library.

npm init
npm install snowboy --save
npm install onoff --save
npm install node-record-lpcm16 --save

Now, train Snowboy to understand your voice. I‚Äôd do this one a laptop with a built-in microphone, not your Pi. Visit Snowboy‚Äôs site (Firefox seemed to work better for me), make an account and create a new hotword. After you repeat the word three times, Snowboy will give you a .pmdl file ‚Äî that‚Äôs the key. Transfer it over to your Pi; I emailed it to myself and just downloaded it from the Pi‚Äôs web browser. I ended up making two hotwords ‚Äî ‚Äúlumos,‚Äù to turn the light on, and ‚Äúnox,‚Äù to turn it off.

Drop the .pmdl file into your project folder, and make index.js, which will contain your main code. Here‚Äôs what I ended up putting together, initializing a detector and adding two hotword models. The detector.on('hotword') function fires whenever I say ‚Äúlumos‚Äù or ‚Äúnox,‚Äù so that‚Äôs where I‚Äôve stuck the pin logic.

Speaking of pins‚Ä¶

Time to wire this together. Here‚Äôs my setup:

I got some basic wiring advice from this tutorial, but essentially, the purple wire connects to one of the Pi‚Äôs ground pins, and the blue wire connects to pin 15. You‚Äôll see that I unscrewed the Powertail‚Äôs casing ‚Äî the terminals were a bit hard to reach with the male end of the wire otherwise.

With finished, you‚Äôre probably ready to give this a shot! I connected the Powertail to an extension cord that plugged into the wall outlet, and then linked the other end of the Powertail with a regular power strip. I ended up plugging three lights into the strip ‚Äî¬†my floor lamp, a desk lamp and my architect light.

When you run node index.js, you should hear a click as the Powertail switches off. (The red LED indicator stays on, so you know it‚Äôs working.) Stand back, and authoritatively say ‚ÄúLumos!‚Äù

With any luck, the light will switch on ‚Äî and you‚Äôll officially be a member of the wizarding world.

entry.title: How to code a virtual Internet of Things device to tempt hackers

link.title: How to code a virtual Internet of Things device to tempt hackers

entry.content:
Earlier this month, hackers used a massive botnet to spam Dyn, a domain name service provider, and block access to dozens of popular websites. It turns out the worm that recruited the botnet targeted IP-connected devices, including an old brand of webcam popular in warehouses and industrial settings.

Scanning the internet for open ports, the Mirai worm connected to unsecured servers and ran through a common dictionary of passwords, including xc3511, which unlocked the webcams. (There‚Äôs a good writeup on the mechanics of the bot here.)

Let me first say that this didn‚Äôt affect many residential users. Very few people plug their devices directly into their modem; pretty much everyone filters their traffic through a router, which has ample safeguards. Plus, many of the devices targeted by Mirai were super old.

All the same, I wondered if this was really a big deal. The internet is huge‚Äîthere are so many IPv4 addresses out there. Even if I had been playing fast and loose with security, weren‚Äôt the odds astronomically small that a hacker would randomly happen across my server and take notice?

So I devised an experiment.

My fake web toaster

I decided to set up a honeypot‚Äîa purposefully unsecured server that would give hackers the illusion of control, but would actually record their keystrokes and IP addresses. I could have used a Raspberry Pi and connected it to my home router (using port forwarding to bypass security), but in the interest of time, I ended up running a virtual server through Amazon‚Äôs EC2 service.

I wrote a Node script that mimicked a Telnet login on port 23, asking for a username and password, and delivering a faux shell prompt. To a hacker‚Äôs scanning script, it would look like a real Telnet server. In honor of one of the internet‚Äôs first connected devices, I had it masquerade as a web-connected toaster. Here‚Äôs what the hacker would have seen when they tried to log in:

I set the thing up and stepped away, expecting to wait a while before recording a hacking attempt. Wrong. The first unauthorized login came within an hour, using root:root as login credentials.

Over the course of the next 12 hours, the server registered around 300 attempted hacks. I wrote about this experiment for The Atlantic here (and talked about it on All Things Considered!)

What does this tell us?

I admit that this project is flawed in a few ways:

  • It wasn‚Äôt a real IoT device. This doesn‚Äôt bother me quite as much; the Mirai bot doesn‚Äôt seem to exploit any device-specific security bugs, so a generic server with an open port fills the role fine. But there‚Äôs no doubt that other worms take advantage of weaknesses inherent to specific IoT gadgets, so it would be interesting to more closely simulate them.
  • I didn‚Äôt conduct the test over residential wireless. I bet hackers closely monitor Amazon‚Äôs IP range, looking for unsecured server instances spun up by rookies. If I had run my script through my apartment‚Äôs internet connection, I probably would have seen fewer login attempts. That said, the security folks I spoke with agreed any unsecured server would have eventually been breached, probably within a day to a week.
  • Most consumer IoT devices don‚Äôt connect to the internet directly. Like I said above, most routers will kill the most obvious routes hackers use to gain control of computers. So the average person hooking up a webcam to their WiFi is probably OK. It would be interesting to simulate the security defects of older routers, and try to get a sense of how many of those exist in the wild.
  • IPv6 might solve these problems. The new protocol allows for way more possible addresses‚Äîlike, 7.9x1028. Assuming addresses were randomly distributed (and I have no idea if they will be, or anything about this protocol beyond what I‚Äôve read on Wikipedia, to be honest), the sheer amount of territory hackers would have to cover might give me the effective anonymity I thought I already had.

I did get a few tweets that linked to this xkcd comic, the thought being that my experiment is nothing new: Security folks have been setting out unsecured honeypots for years.

That said, I think this story illustrates a few things that most people didn‚Äôt know:

  • The Internet isn‚Äôt that big (not yet), and it‚Äôs packed with hacking scripts. Bots scan the IPv4 space frequently enough that nearly every computer that‚Äôs not behind a firewall can count on being recorded in less than a day.
  • The Mirai bot is still out in force. Many of the hack attempts used the same sequence of password (and shell commands) outlined in the Mirai botnet‚Äôs code. It appears other folks have spun up multiple copies of the bot and are busy recruiting unsuspecting servers.

My toaster experiment isn‚Äôt a situation most consumers will face. But it‚Äôs an accurate analog to the plight of the kinds of unsecured devices harnessed by the Mirai botnet, and shows how quickly they can be pulled into a hacker‚Äôs thrall.
entry.summary: Earlier this month, hackers used a massive botnet to spam Dyn, a domain name service provider, and block access to dozens of popular websites. It turns out the worm that recruited the botnet targeted IP-connected devices, including an old brand of webcam popular in warehouses and industrial settings.

entry.title: Make Every Week, Part 4: Ordering a Sweetgreen salad at the press of a button

link.title: Make Every Week, Part 4: Ordering a Sweetgreen salad at the press of a button

entry.content:
Eesh! So far, #MakeEveryWeek has been more like #MakeEveryThreeWeeks. My apologies. Sometimes the making is a lot easier than the blogging.

This week‚Äôs projects focuses on a (sort of) healthy addiction of mine: salads from Sweetgreen, a restaurant chain from D.C. that serves up a mean quinoa-and-kale. Though technically fast food, Sweetgreen doesn‚Äôt feel or taste like your regular rushed-lunch fare. It‚Äôs my go-to place to pick up lunch if I didn‚Äôt bring left overs from home, and it doesn‚Äôt hurt that their Foggy Bottom location is a nice walk from The Atlantic‚Äôs offices.

But a lot of people feel the same way. The line around noon can get verrrrry long.

Unknowingly showed up to sweetgreen in the middle of lunch hour. Now I'm stuck in this long ass line.‚Äî Sextina Aquafina (@yosoymichael) August 15, 2016

There was barely anyone in line today at @sweetgreen. #SignOfTheApocalypse‚Äî Heather Benjamin (@Heather_Benj) August 12, 2016

One remedy to this is Sweetgreen‚Äôs online ordering system, which signals the kitchen to make a salad at a certain time and leave it on a shelf for pick-up. That way, you can pop in, grab and leave, instead of waiting for the salad to be made in front of you.

Last week, I got my second Amazon IoT button‚Äîthey‚Äôre finally back in stock. Then the thought struck me. Is there a way to hook into Sweetgreen‚Äôs ordering system and buy a salad with a simple button press? Could my dream of seamless, on-demand salad delivery come true? Granted, if I had such a device, I‚Äôd probably spend entirely too much on salads. But it was too neat of an idea to pass up.

Since Sweetgreen doesn‚Äôt publish a documented ordering API (and who does?), I had to dive deep into the network traffic of the average salad order.

Figuring out how Sweetgreen works

To complete a Sweetgreen transaction, I need to:

  • log in using my email and password, saving the resulting cookie;
  • add a salad to my shopping bag;
  • complete the order with my credit card information.

Fortunately, Sweetgreen has a relatively simple (though undocumented) API, accessible through https://order.sweetgreen.com/api/. After poking around the website (and adding/removing quite a few salads from my shopping bag), it looks like this is the workflow I‚Äôll have to follow:

  • Send a POST request to https://order.sweetgreen.com/api/customers/login_or_register with my username and password;
  • Add the salad to my bag with a POST request to https://order.sweetgreen.com/api/line_items, along with a JSON object describing the order;
  • Get the ‚Äúorder‚Äù JSON by sending a GET request to https://order.sweetgreen.com/api/session, saving the order object and my billing information;
  • Send a PUT request to https://order.sweetgreen.com/api/orders/[order id], packaging my combined order+billing object.

I‚Äôm writing this code in Node.js using the request module, so I‚Äôm going to start off my script by including the library and setting up the jar where I‚Äôll store the session cookie (so my authentication will stick once I log in.)

var request = require('request');
var cookies = request.jar();
var request = request.defaults({jar: cookies})

Next up, I‚Äôll log in with my Sweetgreen credentials.

// Log in
request.post({
  url: "https://order.sweetgreen.com/api/customers/login_or_register",
  form:{
    customer: {email: INSERT_SWEETGREEN_EMAIL, password: INSERT_SWEETGREEN_PASSWORD} 
  }
}, function(err, response, body){
  if(err) throw err;
  // Rest of code goes here
})

That call returns a massive JSON object, holding previous orders, current shopping status, and billing account info. Since the final package I send to Sweetgreen to complete the order needs some of this account info, I‚Äôm going to grab it now.

var session = JSON.parse(body);
var contact_number = session.customers[0].contact_number
var billing_account_id = session.customers[0].billing_account_ids[0]
var billing_account = session.billing_accounts[0];

We‚Äôre now set to add salads to my shopping bag.

Adding items and completing the order

Each salad object is actually pretty simple. At its most basic, it just needs a quantity, a product_id and a restaurant_id. The Foggy Bottom ID is 6, so I‚Äôll use that for every order. Here‚Äôs the object for a Harvest Bowl:

var harvest_bowl = {
  line_item: {
    quantity: 1,
    product_id: "139",
    restaurant_id: "6"
  }
}

But! Things get more complicated if you want to modify a base recipe. For example, I love the Guacamole Greens salad‚Äîbut only if I can replace the red onion with corn. In the API, you need to drop these changes as a series of options objects. Here‚Äôs an object for my modded recipe, pulled with some slight modifications from the network traffic.

var guac_greens = {
  line_item:{
    quantity:"1",
    custom_name:"andrew's special guac with no onions success",
    product_id:"134",
    options:[{
      id:"13929",
      name:"remove red onion",
      out_of_stock:false,
      quantity:"1",
      parent_option_group_id:"973",
      option_group_ids:["975"],
      ingredient_id:"64",
    },
    {
      id:"13941",
      name:"sub raw corn",
      out_of_stock:false,
      quantity:"1",
      parent_option_group_id:"975",
      option_group_ids:[],
      ingredient_id:"61",
      line_item_id:null
    }],
    restaurant_id:"6"
  }
};

Constructing that object is the hard part, but adding it to the shopping bag is pretty easy. Here comes another POST request:

request.post({
  url: "https://order.sweetgreen.com/api/line_items",
  body: guac_greens,
  json: true
}, function(err, response, body){
  if(err) throw err;
  var order_id = body.line_item.ignored_order_id
});

Notice how I saved the order ID? That‚Äôs because I‚Äôll need it very shortly to complete the transaction. But first, I‚Äôve got to construct the final order object. Turns out that‚Äôs basically a copy of the object you get by calling the /session endpoint, along with some additional billing info and other ordering ephemera. After some trial and error, I figured out it was easiest to make a call to the /session endpoint, grab the array of orders, filter it down to the latest order and tack on the required miscellaneous info.

// Get final order 
request.get("https://order.sweetgreen.com/api/session", function(err, response, body){
  
  // Grab latest order object
  var orders = JSON.parse(body).orders;
  var order = orders.filter(function(d){ return d.id == order_id })[0];
  
  // Append billing stuff and give 
  order.contact_number = contact_number;
  order.billing_account_id = billing_account_id;
  order.wanted_time = order.available_wanted_times_tuples[0].original
  order.state = "complete";
  order.billing_account = billing_account;
});

After that, all you need is a PUT request referencing the order_id and you‚Äôre good to go:

request.put({
  url: "https://order.sweetgreen.com/api/orders/" + order_id,
  body: { order: order },
  json: true
}, function(err, response, body){
  if(err) throw err;
  console.log("did it!")
});

Sweetgreen helpfully sends an email after you post an order, so you‚Äôll know when your order goes through.

Boom! Salad en route

I had to make some slight modifications to the code to get it ready for AWS Lambda, the service powering the IoT button, but it was otherwise pretty much ready to go. I also wrote a quick function that randomly chooses one of three salads to order, so I have a bit of variety. The full code is here.

Here‚Äôs the button posted above my desk at work:

entry.title: Make Every Week, Part 3: How crowded is the Washington, D.C. DMV?

link.title: Make Every Week, Part 3: How crowded is the Washington, D.C. DMV?

entry.content:
First off, an apology: In the aftermath of the July 4th holiday, I took the week off last week. So you‚Äôll see a double #MakeEveryWeek feature coming up soon.

Everyone hates the Department of Motor Vehicles. Over the years, it has somehow become the universal American symbol for a soul-breaking bureaucracy. Washington, D.C.‚Äôs division does its best, but you still end up wondering why it takes to long to get your license renewed.

My wife recently stopped by the DMV in Georgetown. While looking up the office hours for her, I remembered that D.C. does something neat: It streams live webcam footage from the DMV waiting room, so you can get a sense for how crowded your branch is before you go.

It also publishes a calculated wait time, but I‚Äôve never found that particularly accurate. These images are simple JPEGS, very easy to download and parse. So I started thinking: Is there a way to use this footage to detect the ebbs and flows of crowds at the DMV ‚Äî and avoid the rush yourself?

A poor man‚Äôs computer vision

I don‚Äôt have a lot experience with computer vision, though it‚Äôs definitely something I‚Äôd like to explore further. But the DMV did me a favor: They bought those bright blue chairs.

Turns out that blue is pretty distinctive. With the exception of the security guard‚Äôs uniform, there‚Äôs nothing else in the DMV colored quite like it. Counting those blue pixels was key: The more bright blue in the picture, the relatively fewer people waiting in line. If I scraped these pictures every minute or so and ran my script for a few weeks, I could analyze the colors and aggregate my data to make a cool time-series graph.

Here‚Äôs a picture where the matching blue is colored red. Searching for this narrow band of color avoids people (and that newspaper) pretty well.

But there‚Äôs a few things I‚Äôd have to figure out:

  • There are three camera angles (well, four, but the last one‚Äôs just a shot of the door.) The first two are wide shots, and the last one is a bit narrower and shows fewer chairs. I‚Äôd have to calibrate my pixel-counting to compensate.
  • The first two shots actually overlap. One camera shoots down the main waiting room, and the other shoots the opposite angle. It‚Äôs hard to tell, because one has been flipped horizontally. But I‚Äôd have to remove the overlap so people aren‚Äôt double-counted.
  • Lastly, all the cameras show the room at an angle, so chairs in the back will have fewer blue pixels than chairs in the front. I‚Äôd have to compensate for this or risk under-counting the crowd if a few big chairs went unfilled in the front.

On to the code

I wrote this in Node and used a bunch of libraries, but primarily LWIP, an image processing library.

First, I set up an array containing the camera URLs, the vertical position where to start scanning the image, a weight to account for skew and the rough number of empty seats pictured in the photo.

var cameras = [
  {
    url: "https://ftp.dmv.washingtondc.gov/w/gt1/video.jpg",
    start: 90,
    rate_of_change: .976,
    empty_seats: 38
  },
  {
    url: "https://ftp.dmv.washingtondc.gov/w/gt2/video.jpg",
    start: 100,
    rate_of_change: .969,
    empty_seats: 9
  },
  {
    url: "https://ftp.dmv.washingtondc.gov/w/gt4/video.jpg",
    start: 0,
    rate_of_change: .983,
    empty_seats: 24
  }
];

Note that for the first two images, I start processing about 90-100 pixels down. That‚Äôs to remove the chairs that are in the foreground of the other camera angle.

That rate_of_change basically applies less weight to pixels in the foreground than pixels in the background, as each pixel proportionally represents more chair the higher up in the image you go.

Before I do anything with the live images, I want to find out how much blue is in each picture when the room is empty. (I‚Äôve saved copies of footage from when the office is closed. They leave the lights on all night‚Ä¶)

// First, let's calculate the baseline amount of blue for each camera
async.eachOfSeries(cameras, function(camera, i, callback){
  
  // I've saved the photos of the empty DMV room, so let's open those
  fs.readFile("control_images/" + i + ".jpg", function(err, data){
    if(err) throw err;
    var body = new Buffer(data, 'binary');
    lwip.open(body, 'jpeg', function(err, image){
      if( err ) throw err;
      
      // Set the total amount of blue detected to zero
      camera.controlBlue = 0;
      for(y = camera.start; y <= 239; y++){
        for( x = 0; x <= 319; x++){
          var hsv = getHSV(image);
          var pixelScore = y - camera.start * camera.rate_of_change;
          camera.controlBlue += (hsv.h >=220 && hsv.h <= 240 && hsv.s > 30 && hsv.v > 30) ? pixelScore : 0;
        }
      }
      callback();
    });
  });
}, function(){
  console.log("Done setting baseline...");
});

function getHSV(image){
  return Color().rgb([image.getPixel(x,y).r, image.getPixel(x,y).g, image.getPixel(x,y).b]).hsv();
}

I‚Äôm using the awesome aysnc library to keep track of all my callbacks. I cycle through the images, open them a binary file and then parse them row by row and pixel by pixel, testing if they match the blue I‚Äôm looking for and applying the various weights outlined in the cameras object.

Another shoutout to the Color library, which allows you to easily convert RGB values to HSV (hue, saturation, value/brightness). The blue I‚Äôm looking for is in a relatively narrow hue band, is medium saturation and medium-to-high brightness.

After I get the baseline values sorted out, I repeat the same operation with the live images, comparing their blue scores to the empty images to guesstimate how many people are sitting in the chairs.

// Cycle through each of the cameras
async.eachOfSeries(cameras, function(camera, i, callback){
  
  request({url: camera.url, encoding: 'binary'}, function(err, res, body){ 
    var body = new Buffer(body, 'binary');

    lwip.open(body, 'jpeg', function(err, image){
			if(err) throw err;

      // Like above, set the total amount of blue detected to zero
			var blue = 0;
			for(y = camera.start; y <= 239; y++){
				for( x = 0; x <= 319; x++){
				  hsv = getHSV(image);
          pixelScore = y - camera.start * camera.rate_of_change;
					blue += (hsv.h >=220 && hsv.h <= 240 && hsv.s > 30 && hsv.v > 30) ? pixelScore : 0;
				}
			}
      camera.percentBlue = blue / camera.controlBlue;
			totalEmptySeats += camera.percentBlue * camera.empty_seats;
			console.log("Camera " + (i+1) + ": " + camera.percentBlue);
			callback();
    });
  });
});

One that‚Äôs all sorted out, I upload the combined estimate to a MySQL database:

pool.getConnection(function(err, connection){
  connection.query('INSERT INTO readings (timestamp, open_chairs) VALUES(?, ?)', [timestamp.format('YYYY-MM-DD HH:mm:ss'), totalEmptySeats], function(err){
    if( err ) throw err;
    connection.release();
  });
});

Full code is here. I‚Äôm going to run this script for a few weeks and generate data. Once I get a decently! representative sample, I‚Äôll come back with some visualizations!

entry.title: Make Every Week, Part 2: A Slack-powered doorbell

link.title: Make Every Week, Part 2: A Slack-powered doorbell

entry.content:
These days, most office buildings require employees to swipe a keycard or wave an RFID chip to get into their workplace. At The Atlantic, we use a fob to get into our actual office from the elevators or the bathrooms. It‚Äôs great for security. It‚Äôs not always great for the forgetful.

At least once a week, I find myself awkwardly lurking in the hallway after a trip to the restroom, waiting for someone to leave the office, all because I left my fob at my desk. _Hm,_ I think, pretending to look at my phone. Would my health insurance cover the surgery to implant a chip into my body?

After a while, things get really desperate: I knock on the glass door, and someone bemusedly comes over and opens it for me.

The Doorbell

What we needed was a doorbell. Not the ‚ÄúWestminister Chimes‚Äù type ‚Äî that would get annoying fast ‚Äî¬†but something more subtle.

Amazon just released a programmable version of its ‚ÄúDash‚Äù buttons, the little $5 doohickeys that order new paper towels with one tap. It connects to a local WiFi network and executes code through Amazon‚Äôs Lambda service, so it‚Äôs pretty easy to set up.

An idea formed. What if the Dash was connected to a channel in Slack, our work chat client? Folks could opt into the group and receive notifications whenever someone needed help with the door. That way, it wouldn‚Äôt bother the whole office.

The first step was setting up the Slack integration. This was pretty simple, just a matter of telling Slack the name of the ‚Äúbot‚Äù and specifying the channel where it would post messages. Slack then gave an API endpoint to use to send data.

Next, Lambda. I wrote this code in Node.js, though you can use another language if you‚Äôd like. Lambda lets you write the code in-browser if it‚Äôs a single script, but since I needed to send HTTP POST requests as per Slack‚Äôs incoming webhooks standard, I chose to use the popular request library and upload a zipped folder instead.

Lambda expects everything to be contained in a module export, so laying that out came first:

exports.handler = function(event, context){
  var request = require('request');
}

Then came the actual call to the Slack endpoint, which was a pretty simple POST request: Just the bot‚Äôs username, an emoji to use for the bot‚Äôs userpic and the message to post.

request.post(slack_endpoint, 
  {
    form: {
      payload: '{"username": "doorbellbot", "icon_emoji": ":bellhop_bell:", "text": "<!group> Someone is at the door! Let \'em in"}'
    }
  },
  function (error, response, body) {
    if(error) throw error;
    console.log(response);
  }
);

You‚Äôll notice that I‚Äôm using <!group> to simulate a ‚Äú@group‚Äù string in the message, which pings everyone in the channel. Just typing ‚Äú@group‚Äù doesn‚Äôt work‚Äîyou‚Äôll need to use that code.

It worked!

That wrapped up quicker than I thought, so I added a bit of fun. Every time the doorbell rang, I wanted the bot to print a random quote about opening doors. I found a few online and encoded them as JSON, writing a command to pick a random one:

var quotes = [
  { 
    quote: "Good manners will open doors that the best education cannot.",
    author: "Clarence Thomas"
  },
  { 
    quote: "I think there are influences that you open the door to, and influences that come under the door.",
    author: "Harrison Birtwistle"
  },
  { 
    quote: "We must open the doors of opportunity. But we must also equip our people to walk through those doors.",
    author: "Lyndon B. Johnson"
  },
  { 
    quote: "I find that when you open the door toward openness and transparency, a lot of people will follow you through.",
    author: "Kirsten Gillibrand"
  },
  { 
    quote: "Not knowing when the dawn will come\nI open every door.",
    author: "Emily Dickinson"
  },
  { 
    quote: "In life sometimes, in the universe, you have to close some doors to have others open.",
    author: "Gene Ween"
  },
  { 
    quote: "Knowledge of what is does not open the door directly to what should be.",
    author: "Albert Einstein"
  },
  { 
    quote: "When one door closes, another opens; but we often look so long and so regretfully upon the closed door that we do not see the one which has opened for us.",
    author: "Alexander Graham Bell"
  },
];

var this_quote = quotes[Math.floor(Math.random() * quotes.length)];

I then rewrote my POST payload to this:

payload: '{"username": "doorbellbot", "icon_emoji": ":bellhop_bell:", "text": "<!group> Someone is at the door! Let \'em in.\n>\\"' + this_quote.quote + '\\" \n>- ' + this_quote.author + '"}'

‚Ä¶ and tada!

All that remained was to post the IoT button by our office door. I attached near the fob reader and left it mysterious for now‚Ä¶ maybe I‚Äôll add a fun sign later.

That‚Äôs it for week 2! Here‚Äôs the whole code.

At The Atlantic, we use a fob to get into our actual office from the elevators or the bathrooms. It‚Äôs great for security. It‚Äôs not always great for the forgetful.

entry.title: Make Every Week, Part 1: A bikeshare smartwatch app

link.title: Make Every Week, Part 1: A bikeshare smartwatch app

entry.content:
In 2015, WNYC journalist and developer John Keefe made up his mind to build a new thing every week. By the end of the year, he had designed a wind-sensing candle,, a homemade fitness wristband, a lunch-suggesting Slack bot, and much more. I loved following along throughout the year and seeing what he thought of next.

So here‚Äôs my own resolution: Every week this summer, I‚Äôll build something new myself. It‚Äôll ideally have some presence in the physical world, though I‚Äôll probably have a few lazy weeks and build web-only tools. And it can‚Äôt be something I‚Äôm already doing for work, because that‚Äôs cheating.

Beyond that, I‚Äôll avoid being too picky. I want to keep the pump of creativity primed; it‚Äôs a lot easier to think of new ideas when you‚Äôre already working on something!

On that note, let‚Äôs look at the first project: a smartwatch app that tells Capital Bikeshare users how many bicycles are available at nearby docks.

Capital Bikeshare smartwatch app

This project connects two of my favorite things, both built by teams of passionate people:

  • Washington, D.C.‚Äôs Capital Bikeshare. This citywide program puts low-cost commuter bikers within easy reach of residents. If you‚Äôre a member, you can use a key fob to check out one of the thousands of bikes docked throughout the District, Maryland and Virginia. Once you reach your destination, you lock it at the nearest dock. It‚Äôs a great one-way transportation system that I used quite frequently before I upgraded my own bicycle.
  • The Pebble smartwatch. A Kickstarter-funded project, Pebble is an awesome alternative to mainstream smartwatches like the Apple Watch, offering an e-ink display, great battery life and most of the features you‚Äôd expect. Best of all, it‚Äôs super easy to develop for Pebble, both in C and in Javascript.

As much as I love Capital Bikeshare, I dread rolling up to my office after a long commute and discovering other commuters have already claimed all the bike docks. It always looks clear when I check the Spotcycle app at the beginning of my ride ‚Äî¬†but the racks often fill up while I‚Äôm huffing and puffing along. And fiddling with my phone mid-ride, trying to get an update, sounds like a good way to end up in the hospital.

But what if my Pebble could tell me whether the upcoming bike rack was full?

Building the app

Most Pebble apps are written in C. But to prototype my bikeshare app, I used Pebble.js, a framework that allows you to program your Pebble using Javascript. It‚Äôs limited and a bit laggy, since most of the computing takes place on your phone, but it‚Äôs very quick to get running.

For my data source, I pulled two JSON feeds from Capital Bikeshare‚Äôs station map: station_information.json and station_status.json. Capital Bikeshare would rather developers use its official XML feed, but since Pebble.js is notoriously bad at parsing non-JSON models, I opted for a hackier solution.

First, I needed to throw up a loading screen while the app pulled data and found the user‚Äôs location. Pebble.js mostly works by displaying Cards, which are standalone screen with a title, subtitle and body text, and Menus, which are scrollable lists. Here‚Äôs the code for a loading card:

var card = new UI.Card({
  title: 'Capital Bikeshare',
  subtitle: "Getting bikeshare data..."
});

card.show();

Pebble.js uses a version of jQuery‚Äôs ajax function to make HTTP requests. Here, I pull in both feeds using nested AJAX calls:

ajax(
 {
   url: "https://api-core.capitalbikeshare.com/gbfs/en/station_information.json",
   type: "json"
 },
 function(info){
   // Got station info 
   ajax(
     {
       url: "https://api-core.capitalbikeshare.com/gbfs/en/station_status.json",
       type: "json"
     },
     function(status){       
      // Got status of stations
      
      // Rest of code goes here
      
     },
     function(err){ throw err; }
   );
 },
 function(err){ throw err; }
);

The bike availability data I need is in station_status.json, but that file only contains very little information about the stations themselves ‚Äî only a numerical ID. So you have to cut in the station metadata from station_information.json.

// Make array of station ids 
var station_ids = info.data.stations.map(function(d){ return d.station_id; });

// For each station status, add in metadata about the station
status.data.stations.forEach(function(station){
  var station_info = info.data.stations[station_ids.indexOf(station.station_id)];
  station.name = station_info.name;
  station.latitude = station_info.lat;
  station.longitude = station_info.lon;
  station.capacity = station_info.capacity;
});

Next up: The user‚Äôs current position. This is actually a snap, since Pebble.js allows you to use Javascript‚Äôs native navigator.geolocation function. I use a Haversine distance function (borrowed with thanks from this library!) to sort the array of stations by their distance from the user, from nearest to farthest.

navigator.geolocation.getCurrentPosition(function(position){
  var user = {
    latitude: position.coords.latitude,
    longitude: position.coords.longitude
  }
  
  // Sort by station distance
  status.data.stations.sort(function(a,b){
    return haversine(user, a) - haversine(user, b);
  });
  
});

Lastly, I build a Menu object using the closest 10 stations. Menu objects accept a title and and a list of of items, each of which have a title of their own and an optional subtitle. You‚Äôll notice I also attach a select event to the Menu, which creates a new card showing expanded details about the station.

// Loop through the top 10 stations closest to the user
var menu_items = [];
for( i=0; i<=9; i++){
  menu_items.push({
    title: status.data.stations[i].name,
    subtitle: status.data.stations[i].num_bikes_available + " bikes/" + status.data.stations[i].capacity
  })
}

var resultsMenu = new UI.Menu({
  sections: [{
    title: "Nearest stations:",
    items: menu_items
  }],
  highlightBackgroundColor: "#EC008C",
  highlightColor: "black"
});

resultsMenu.on('select', function(e){
  var station = status.data.stations[e.itemIndex]
  var stationCard = new UI.Card({
    title: station.name,
    body: "Bikes available: " + station.num_bikes_available
      + "\nDocks available: " + station.num_docks_available,
    scrollable: true
  })
  stationCard.show();
})

resultsMenu.show();
card.hide();

And that‚Äôs it! Here‚Äôs the app in action (and full code here):

By the end of the year, he had designed a wind-sensing candle,, a homemade fitness wristband, a lunch-suggesting Slack bot, and much more. I loved following along throughout the year and seeing what he thought of next.

entry.title: Building ‚ÄúOmniturebot,‚Äù a Slack bot for keeping tabs on traffic

link.title: Building ‚ÄúOmniturebot,‚Äù a Slack bot for keeping tabs on traffic

entry.content:
One of my everyday frustrations as a journalist is the veritable symphony of mouse clicks required to get web traffic stats for your stories.

Yes, Chartbeat is super easy to use. But it only tracks concurrent users, not unique visitors or pageviews, which your bosses actually care about. And pulling those stats from Google Analytics or Omniture quickly devolves into a multi-step nightmare that makes setting the clock on your microwave after a power outage look downright enjoyable.

At The Atlantic, we use Omniture, or whatever Adobe is calling it these days. We also use Slack, the popular work chat client, which offers extensive scripting and automation capabilities.

After a day of one too many segment-selections and filter-applications, I asked myself, couldn‚Äôt a robot do this better?

Enter Omniturebot. It‚Äôs a Slack bot that uses your Omniture credentials to pull traffic stats at a moment‚Äôs notice, accepting a keyword and a timespan and returning the relevant stats.

Using it, getting my most recent stats is as easy as chatting @omniturebot and asking "andrew mcgill" (1 month). It‚Äôll happily return:

Omniturebot is written in Node.js and can easily be deployed via Heroku or any SaaS provider. (You can also easily run it in your local environment, if you‚Äôd prefer.) It‚Äôs written to handle multiple users, though admittedly I haven‚Äôt tested against a ton of concurrent requests.

I hope it makes pulling traffic numbers as easy and enjoyable as it has for me!
